name: Kirillov's conjecture
rephrased: A nilpotent Lie algebra's irreducible representations can be built from its abelian subalgebras.
implication_form: If a Lie algebra is nilpotent, then all its irreducible representations can be constructed using its abelian subalgebras.
explained: Kirillov's conjecture concerns the irreducibility of certain representations of linear algebraic groups over p-adic fields. It states that for a representation π of the group G = GL(n,F) (where F is a p-adic field) that is irreducible and essentially tempered, the representation π(g.f) (the restriction to the Borel subgroup B) is irreducible for all g not in the unipotent radical of B. More precisely, for the standard representation π_θ (induced from the Borel subgroup with a character θ), the conjecture asserts that π_θ(g.f) is irreducible for all g not in the unipotent radical of B. The conjecture is known to hold for real groups (n arbitrary) and for p-adic groups in low dimensions (n ≤ 3), but remains open for higher dimensions (n ≥ 4).
